meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>yoga</radical> class uses a special <radical>brush</radical> to stay <kanji>healthy</kanji>. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.
meaning_hint: If you want to be healthy too, just do yoga and rub this healthy brush all over your bod.
reading_mnemonic: Not everyone wants to be <kanji>healthy</kanji>, but <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.
reading_hint: Imagine Ken, the picture of samurai health, doing yoga and getting that brush all up in those bits.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>capital</radical>, even a broken <radical>dog</radical> can <kanji>get a position</kanji>. That's because the capital has so many jobs available that even a poor, broken dog can find a place to work.
meaning_hint: Imagine this dog going to the capital and getting a position. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
reading_mnemonic: In order to help the dog <kanji>get a position</kanji>, the capital cobbler made him a pair of nice <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they boost his confidence and make him feel ready for any position.
reading_hint: Watch the broken dog settle in to his new shoes in his new home in the capital. The old dog can finally enjoy life!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> by the <radical>exit</radical> letting you know to <kanji>yield</kanji>. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
meaning_hint: Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
reading_mnemonic: Even though the flag told you to <kanji>yield</kanji>, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old <reading>coots</reading> (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!
reading_hint: Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>canopy</radical> under which someone has left a <radical>brush</radical> (in its 肀 form) next to the <radical>water</radical>, creating a scene of such <kanji>ease</kanji> and <kanji>peace</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Imagine the sense of peace you'd feel in a place like this. The sound of the water, the shade of the canopy… Whoever was here must have felt at ease as they wrote or drew. But will they come back for their brush?
reading_mnemonic: It turns out this place of <kanji>ease</kanji> and <kanji>peace</kanji> was created by <reading>こう</reading>いち, who suddenly comes in looking for the brush he left.
reading_hint: Finding you there, こういち invites you spend some time under the canopy with him, practicing kanji together with his brush. Why not? Seems peaceful.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> with a broken <radical>heart</radical> is very <kanji>angry</kanji>. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
meaning_hint: This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
reading_mnemonic: As you're sitting on that stool feeling <kanji>angry</kanji>, your <reading>do</reading>g (ど) comes up to console you. He nuzzles his head into your lap, and you start to feel the anger melt away.
reading_hint: Imagine your dog (or somebody else's dog) putting his furry, warm head in your lap. Feel how comforting it is. Are you still feeling angry?

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is lying in the <radical>grass</radical> in a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, you're going to <kanji>worry</kanji> about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.
meaning_hint: Picture your soul curled up inside this treasure chest that's just sitting out on the grass. Anyone could open it up and look inside, and this worries you quite a bit!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also <kanji>worry</kanji> about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? <reading>Nah, yah</reading> (なや). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.
reading_hint: You worry about what you'll find if you look directly at your soul. But you also worry about what will happen if someone else looks. So you're stuck in a constant state of worrying: nah or yah?!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> who has his <radical>mouth</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, has a <radical>heart</radical> that is <kanji>misguided</kanji>. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.
meaning_hint: Picture this misguided drunkard. His whole deal is messed up.
reading_mnemonic: Nowadays we don't say <kanji>misguided</kanji>, we say <reading>wack</reading> (わく). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.
reading_hint: Did I do it? Did I figure out the kid lingo? Am I cool? Or am I just another wack, misguided adult?

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in the <radical>village</radical> you <kanji>long for</kanji>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <kanji>yearn</kanji> for it.
meaning_hint: Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
reading_mnemonic: No matter how much you <kanji>long for</kanji> it, you can't go back because <reading>a cougar</reading> (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.
reading_hint: You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!

meaning_mnemonic: Someone is reaching out with their <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>call</radical> for you. They <kanji>beckon</kanji> you closer, this way.
meaning_hint: Something about the way they're beckoning you with their fingers is really enticing. You can't help but walk toward them.
reading_mnemonic: The person <kanji>beckon</kanji>ing you is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.
reading_hint: Even if the Shougun didn't have an army that would crush you if you didn't come when he called, you'd go anyway. Those beckoning fingers are just so... weirdly enticing.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to go to the <radical>sun</radical> so you set up a <radical>slide</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> stories tall so you can <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the heavens.
meaning_hint: Feel the air whoosh past your face as you shoot off the end of the long slide and ascend into the air. It's starting to get hot and the sun is getting closer!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the sky and toward the sun because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.
reading_hint: As you ascend, look back through tear-filled eyes and see the Shougun staring up at you. He nods slightly. You've pleased him.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>sun</radical> while holding a <radical>comb</radical> in a <radical>cage</radical> and sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, you comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
reading_mnemonic: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>, you used to steal <reading>ca</reading>rs (か). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.
reading_hint: Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.

meaning_mnemonic: There aren't many <radical>tree</radical>s in your under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>prison</radical>, so you've been given a task: using only your <radical>mouth</radical> and a <radical>stool</radical>, plant as many in the <radical>ground</radical> as you can. It's an <kanji>extreme</kanji> challenge!
meaning_hint: How are you going to approach this weirdly specific, extreme task? Dig a hole using the stool and then plant the trees with your mouth? Good luck figuring this one out! You're in a weird underground prison for a reason, after all.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>extreme</kanji> challenge could only be solved by one person: <reading>Goku</reading> (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z! He has a special cloak that'll allow you to plant trees in record time, so he quickly <reading>cloaks you</reading> (きょく) to help with your extreme task.
reading_hint: Goku barely manages to cloak you before the prison guards realize what's going on. With this cloak, you'll be planting trees with your mouth and stool like no one else before! Hooray!

vocabulary.meaning: To Reach The Peak Of Something
To Get To The Bottom Of

meaning_mnemonic: Cut this <radical>comb</radical> up with your <radical>weapon</radical> and turn it into the <kanji>steps</kanji> for some <kanji>stairs</kanji>.
meaning_hint: When you think about it, a comb is like a ladder. So if you cut all the rungs off with your weapon and put them on the ground, they turn into stairs!
reading_mnemonic: You slowly work to create these <kanji>stairs</kanji>, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at <reading>dawn</reading> (だん) they are done!
reading_hint: Imagine standing at the top of the stairs you made yourself, looking down at the entire town below you, as the light of dawn breaks and fills everything before you with light. And now more people can see this beautiful sight if they climb your steps.

meaning_mnemonic: After a <radical>tsunami</radical> hit your <radical>farming</radical> land, you're gonna see a lot of <kanji>dense</kanji> silt left behind. This <kanji>thick</kanji> layer really enriches the soil, and your crops will come out tasting extra thick and dense in flavor.
meaning_hint: Imagine your farming land absolutely covered with this dense layer of silt from the tsunami, but then seeing your crops sprouting up one after another, thicker than ever. It’s all very thick and dense, we think you get the point.
reading_mnemonic: Know who’s likely responsible for this <kanji>dense</kanji>, <kanji>thick</kanji> layer of silt? <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう). He’s the one who urged you to buy this farmland in the first place, likely because he predicted the tsunami would bring this thick layer of silt.
reading_hint: You can always rely on Nostradamus’ predictions hitting the mark, even when it comes to thickly-layered-silt-bringing tsunamis. Good ol’ reliable Nostradamus.

meaning_mnemonic: When someone is <radical>sick</radical> in order to diagnose the <radical>correct</radical> cause and treatment, you need to check their <kanji>symptom</kanji>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
meaning_hint: If you know all of the symptoms for each and every sickness you'd be able to cure them all!
reading_mnemonic: You need to figure out the <kanji>symptom</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.
reading_hint: You get all up close and personal with the Shougun. Hmm, his symptoms are watery eyes, stuffy nose, angry shouting (wait no, that's not a symptom, is it?). Don't mess up!

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>sick</radical> <radical>mama</radical> tries to do a <radical>task</radical> she's filled with <kanji>pain</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Sick people shouldn't have to do things, of course they're in pain. You shouldn't let your mama do anything if she's in pain, do it for her!
reading_mnemonic: Your mama's <kanji>pain</kanji> is <reading>too</reading> (つう) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.
reading_hint: You finish doing your tasks and hers too, and you ask her, "How is the pain now, Mama?" "THE PAIN IS TOO MUCH!" she cries. Oh mama.

meaning_mnemonic: Closing each <radical>eye</radical> is something that the <radical>peoples</radical> do before they <kanji>sleep</kanji>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
meaning_hint: You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
reading_mnemonic: The reason you want to <kanji>sleep</kanji> is because all the other peoples were <reading>mean</reading> (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.
reading_hint: Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as 民, which is included in this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>eye</radical>s start to close as you drive your <radical>car</radical> because you’re getting <kanji>drowsy</kanji>. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
meaning_hint: Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
reading_mnemonic: The reason you’re so <kanji>drowsy</kanji>, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.

meaning_mnemonic: Setting up a <radical>stand</radical> on the top of a <radical>mountain</radical>, you <radical>rake</radical> all the rocks to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
reading_mnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). You lie next to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a special <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>towel</radical> you can use to make it <radical>stand</radical> up by <kanji>tighten</kanji>ing it.
meaning_hint: Imagine pulling this thread and watch as your towel tightens and goes rigid, standing up almost completely on its own (except that the thread did it).
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>tighten</kanji> your towel before you eat <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.
reading_hint: A tightened towel stands up for easy grease cleanup. No wiping on your pants, no dripping on the floor.

meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>thread</radical> and moving to the <radical>sound</radical> of the music, a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes a <kanji>weave</kanji> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
reading_mnemonic: This drunkard is really <reading>chic</reading> (しき), but he's just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he's using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy chic outfits.
reading_hint: Imagine this drunkard, and his chic but shabby appearance. Let's hope he can repair that chic outfit and go back to being his usual chic self.

meaning_mnemonic: If you eat a <radical>rice paddy</radical> the size of the <radical>moon</radical>, your <kanji>stomach</kanji> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
reading_mnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended <kanji>stomach</kanji>. Bam! The <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.
reading_hint: This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside this <radical>moon</radical> is a <radical>black hole</radical>... haha just kidding, it's your <kanji>belly</kanji>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <kanji>stomach</kanji> you have!
meaning_hint: Look down at your perfect belly. It's looking back up at you.
reading_mnemonic: If you don't treat your <kanji>belly</kanji> with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach!
reading_hint: Forget to eat lunch? Belly grumbles f**k you. Tell someone you're fat and need to lose weight? Belly cries f**k you. Be nice to your belly.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone just asked you to <radical>say</radical> which <radical>direction</radical> they should <kanji>visit</kanji>.
meaning_hint: You better think long and hard about where you think they should visit before you say so. They're relying on you.
reading_mnemonic: You end up saying, "You should <kanji>visit</kanji> my <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう)." How kind of you!
reading_hint: Your home is just over that direction, and it's your favorite place to visit, so why wouldn't this stranger want to visit your home too?! So come and visit my home, random person!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> you've left some <radical>grain</radical> on the <radical>stairs</radical>. This is how you <kanji>invite</kanji> people into your place.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself saying out loud how you've left grain on the stairs, trying to lure people in. You're surprised people are actually falling for this.
reading_mnemonic: You've <kanji>invite</kanji>d people in by leaving grain on the stairs but some <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) have ended up eating all the grain.
reading_hint: Imagine the youths just loitering in the stairs having eaten all the grain and taking up all the space making it impossible for anyone else to come in.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>substitute</radical> some <radical>shellfish</radical> for collateral so your friend will <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
meaning_hint: "Shellfish used to be money! People used to lend them to each other all the time!" you say to your friend. "Hmm... okay, I guess so," they say skeptically.
reading_mnemonic: You want your friend to <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money so you can buy yourself a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>white</radical>. This color will <kanji>urge</kanji> and <kanji>compel</kanji> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <kanji>coerce</kanji> you, even.
meaning_hint: Look at how white the scooter is. It urges you to use it. It compels you. You feel coerced...
reading_mnemonic: When they <kanji>urge</kanji>, <kanji>compel</kanji> and <kanji>coerce</kanji> you like this, they are <reading>hack</reading>ing (はく) your brain.
reading_hint:
Really all marketing, advertising, and the like is just a hack of your brain.

Hint: If you see 白 in a kanji, there's a good likelihood the reading will be はく.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're riding your <radical>scooter</radical> through some <radical>rice</radical>, it's likely you've gone <kanji>astray</kanji>. Also you might be <kanji>lost</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Usually there aren't paved areas inside areas of rice. You must be really lost if you ended up here with your scooter.
reading_mnemonic: You got so <kanji>lost</kanji> and went so <kanji>astray</kanji> you ended up on the <reading>May</reading>flower  (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.
reading_hint: How you got so lost that you ended up on an old ship from 1620 is beyond my understanding. But you did it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on your <radical>scooter</radical> and you run over a <radical>root</radical>, you'll need to <kanji>retreat</kanji>. The roots have obviously <kanji>reject</kanji>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should.
meaning_hint: Picture the roots raising up a little bit from the ground and tripping up your scooter. They reject you, so you should just retreat.
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>retreat</kanji> by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your <reading>tie</reading> (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.
reading_hint: You didn't retreat fast enough, the roots are rejecting your life, and strangling you with your own tie.

meaning_mnemonic: When you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> you'll have a <radical>surplus</radical> of possible <kanji>route</kanji>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
meaning_hint: Okay, so it might not be legal to take the sidewalk route depending on where you live, but physically, you can do whatever you want because scooters are small.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to take the fastest <kanji>route</kanji>, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single <reading>toe</reading> (と) on every single person trying to walk there.
reading_hint: Psh, whatever. They aren't your toes, and this is the fastest route! You'll name it the toe route and do whatever you want.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside the "<radical>Good</radical> <radical>Building</radical>" there's a single <kanji>guy</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Feel free to walk around the Good Building. There are no things or people, except for that one guy. Who is that guy.
reading_mnemonic: You talk to that <kanji>guy</kanji>. The only thing he does is offer you <reading>roe</reading> (ろう).
reading_hint: You try to talk to the guy, poke him, and even yell at him. But, all he does is hand you some fish roe. When you take it, he offers you more fish roe. What's up with this guy?

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>leather</radical> and <radical>change</radical> it into <kanji>shoes</kanji>.
meaning_hint: You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
reading_mnemonic: Some <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old <reading>coots</reading> (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.
reading_hint: Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.
